div1.p: The first test pressings arrived and the quality was excellent but they forgot to make them with speeparations between the sections so I am having them cut them over again. I will send you a copy as soon as they finish the second cut. I am now wiaiting for Bill to make up his mind what he wants to do so I will know what to put on the album, Artists Recording Studios, or Orpheus Records. Everything else is ready to tgo and once I give the various companyies concerned the go ahead the records will be done withingwithin two weeks. This means that we can still have them done by the middle of March.

Bill worrote and said that he would be interested in a one third interest if we send out a mailer first. This would delay things at least two months and probably longer so I told him that I planned to go ahead with them now since I already had quite a bit tied up in them. I am waiting for the repyly to this letter now; I imagine (and hope) that he will not be inte4rested.

By the way, the first paragraph of the material for the back of the almbum reads as follows: Gone practically without trace but for motto-stamped relics, Hollywood pipe-dreams, and lists of dates and names in history books, is the frontier spirit that carved this nation from a raw continent. The frontier era covered the greater part of the whiteman's span in America; this was the period wof his greatest vitality, and it has left permanent and pervasive marks on the national character -- yet it has only been in recent years that men capable of chronicaling the spirit of that time for posterity have turned to it for subject and inspiration. The hisotorian can arragnearrange and label the fossil facts; only the writer of imaginative literature can show "the very age and body of the time is"is" circled and linked to a ? form and pressure."

In Ockie's original copy the last quote (I imagine it is from one of your prefaces and I don't have the mateirial here to check it) reads thus: "the very age and body of the time his"his" circled and linked to a ? form and pressure." I changed the 'his' to an 'is.' Is this correc6t? Or is it supposed to be 'has'?

I just read your The River and I. It is quite exciting and I am eager to hop in a boat and start coasting, or pulling or pushing as the case may be. I think the film iaddea has a good chance of selling and I think it would be an exciting thing to film. The script I mentioned in my last letter doesn't have to be anything more than a rough word picture of the various points of interest along the way.

Does this suddent burst of enthusiasm surprise you? It shouldn't since you are responsible for it. As I said once before, I have gained much from our friendship, but I think the most valuable thing you helped me recapture was my enthusiamsm and eagerness for life. A professor I have out here said in class the other day thatyyou only fail when you stop trying. And until I met you I had become a failure because I did stop trying. But I'm done with that attituede!

I am encolsingenclosing one of the photographs I took at your place before I left Columbia. This is not a very good print but the negative is cabablecapable of a good print. What do you think of using it for the cover of one of the future albums. Do you like enough for that purpose? I don't have an extra print for theof the one I'm using for this album but I think you will like it. It is the one I took through the door of you in your library.
